text: Honorable member Sri K. Frances Ji.
Thank you sir. I rise today to engage in
a critical discussion on the recently
passed protection of interest in
aircraft objects bill
2025. While this legisl legislation aims
to align India's aviation aviation laws
with international standards. So
particularly the Cape Town Convention,
it is imperative to scrutinize its
implications within the broader context
of our nation's aviation challenges.
Sir, at the outset, I acknowledge the
government's intent to provide legal
clarity in aircraft leasing and
financing by implementing the Cape Town
Convention and its protocol. This move
is anticipated to bolster the aircraft
leasing industry in India, potentially
reducing operational costs for airlines
and ideally leading to more affordable
air travel for our citizens. However
sir, as a representative from Kerala, I
must highlight the pressing issues that
continue to plur our state's air
connectivity. Sir, discontinuation of
vital flight routes. The recent
termination of direct flights such as
the Kochi London route by Air India. I
had discussed the matter with the
honorable minister has severed essential
links for our expatriate community and
students abroad. So this decision
despite high demand disrupts lives and
livelihoods. cancellation on key
domestic and uh domestic and
international routes. The suspension of
services on routes like Beharin
Tiranapuram and Kochi Delhi by Air India
Express excessbates the challenges faced
by travelers especially during peak uh
festive seasons. So many passengers
complain that in international flights
uh via Delhi or Mumbai to Kerala through
booking of luggage to find the final
destination is not allowed.
So the cumulative effect of reduced
connectivity is the surge in ticket
prices making air travel prohibitively
expensive for the average citizen. This
trend not only affects personal travel
but also hampers business and tourism
vital components of careless economy
sir. So sir while the protection of
interest in aircraft objects bill
addresses certain aspects of the
aviation sector it remains silent on the
regulation of airfares. The absence of a
regulatory mechanism allows airlines to
set prices that may not reflect fair
market practices leading to exploitation
of passengers especially in regions with
limited alternatives. So to truly to
truly revitalize India's aviation sector
sir and to ensure equality benefits for
all regions. One one minute no please
come. I propose the following measures
sir. Establishment of an airfare
regulatory authority. a dedicated body
to oversee and regulate ticket pricing.
Ensuring transparency and fairness is
essential. This will prevent arbitrary
pricing and protect consumers from
exorbitant fires. Restoration and
expansion of flight routes. The
government must actively engage with
airlines to reinstate discontinued
routes and introduce new ones
particularly connecting particularly
connecting and underserved regions like
Kerala to major domestic and
international destinations. Sir, so
there has been long-standing request
from Kerala uh to give Cano airport sir
the point of call status for more
